orking on this approaches, I will be also at Gecco in the

y) =3D z is enougth, far simpl=
ier and have a much better algorithmic

But those developmenta=
l encodings are not meant to be used to make
flags and only flags. They can=
 use environmental information to
provide a solution to a problem for diffe=
rents contexts. A

of bridge,

.. Or
we can imagine that each 'cells' of the embryo could have and
informa=
tion a physical information, and then the embryo would converge

al structure. With a single evolution we could solve
severals problems. Tha=
t's the real power of the embryogenic
approaches. I spoke about "convergenc=
e" : that means that with an
embryogenic approache, we simply defines the s=
olution of problem the
fixed point of cells interaction. This convergence, =
if the evolution

l

pmental encodings". It will probably works for Gecco :D

--- In neat@=
yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Ian, thanks fo=
r the great post.  These are indeed critical and deep 
> issues at the core=
 of indirect encoding.
> 
> I want to carefully address them because I have=
 been thinking about 
> these issues for a long time and they are tied into=
 the theory 
> behind CPPNs.  
> 
> First, note that our new journal paper =
that I just 
> announced, "Compositional Pattern Producing Networks: A Nove=
l 
> Abstraction of Development," gives an extensive treatment of the 
> is=
sues you raise in a better way than the old "Patterns Without 
> Developmen=
t."  (The journal paper has replaced "Patterns Without 
> Development," whi=
ch is no longer available)  So you may find a 
> better motivation in that =
paper.
> 
> In any case, I will give my thoughts here in short.  I have com=
e to 
> the conclusion after thinking about this issue for a couple years 
=
> that there may be no representational or even computational 
> advantage =
to iterated developmental systems over CPPN-like 
> functional representati=
on.  I say "may" because I am not yet 100% 
> certain, but I am nearing it.=
  If I am right, this is a very deep 
> and significant fact that should ch=
ange the way we are looking at 
> representation through development.  
> 
=
> There are a few reasons for this view.  One is the simple 
> theoretical =
fact that a single hidden layer neural network can 
> represent any functio=
n with arbitrary accuracy (a theorem by 
> Cybenko).  From the perspective =
of patterns, this theorem means that 
> *theoretically*, there is no patter=
n that iterative development can 
> produce that a functional description c=
annot describe with 
> arbitrarily close precision.
> 
> Of course, that is=
 only theory, and theory and practice are often 
> opposed:  It still leave=
s open the possibility that somehow 
> representations of certain patterns =
are for some reason more 
> *compact* if they are described and mapped thro=
ugh an iterative 
> process.  Thus one can still argue they are more powerf=
ul.
> 
> Yet I also have come to believe that that is not the case either. =
 
> The reason hinges on an interesting insight that you put like this:
> 
=
> "genes essentially 'pattern recognize' certain areas in the  
> organism"=

> 
> That is absolutely correct for biological organisms, and for 
> itera=
ted developmental systems in general.  However, the deep 
> question is *wh=
y* should they need to "pattern recognize" certain 
> areas?
> 
> And the a=
nswer is because they need to know where they are.  In 
> effect, in the ph=
ysical universe, there is no intrinsic coordinate 
> system that cells can =
query to ask their location.  Thus, they must 
> develop elaborate and ad h=
oc ways of communicating to each other, as 
> a group, where everyone is.  =
I send my neighbor signals, my neighbor 
> sends me signals back, and we ne=
gotiate our roles. 
> 
> My undoubtedly controversial contention is that th=
e question "where 
> am I?" is the ONLY reason that such negotation is nece=
ssary.  If you 
> didn't have to ask that question, then you would not need=
 to talk to 
> your neighbors in order to determine your role.  Rather, you=
 could 
> just compute your role as a function of your known 
> coordinate/=
position in the world.  
> 
> That is exactly what CPPNs do.  Because insid=
e a computer the 
> coordinates of every "cell" in (2D or 4D or 6D or whate=
ver) space is 
> known, they do not need to communicate with each other.  R=
ather, 
> they simply compute a function of their position.
> 
> That funct=
ion in effect encompasses all the unfolding events that 
> would happen in =
a normal iterative process, as the CPPN theory 
> says.  So if there was a =
symmetric gradient laid from one side to 
> another in a growing organism t=
hrough some complex process of 
> communication, a CPPN simply instantiates=
 a symmetric function 
> instead as an analogue of the same process.  
> 
>=
 Thus, I would argue that the CPPN likely completely subsumes 
> iterative =
development, and that all the fancy stuff that is so mind-
> blowing that l=
ooks so important in devleopmental biology is simply a 
> big complicated q=
uest to answer the question "where am I?" (and 
> hence "who am I?").  In a=
 computer, since we know the "where" answer 
> a priori by definition, we c=
an wipe out all of this unnecessary 
> complexity, in effect massively simp=
lifying the problem of 
> represnetation.
> 
> My hunch is that this princi=
ple is why CPPNs are producing such 
> intricate and complex structures com=
pared to every artificial 
> developmental encoding that has come before.  =
Have you ever seen a 
> pattern as nuanced and intricate as the spaceship p=
roduced by CPPNs 
> produced by another developmental encoding?  In fact, e=
volving a 
> blob or a flag-like pattern is currently considered cutting ed=
ge 
> with such systems today.
> 
> So I'd actually argue that CPPNs are a =
more powerful representation 
> than an iterative system because they wipe =
out all kinds of 
> unnecessary complexity that results at the core from si=
mply needing 
> to know where one is in the body plan.  And they also wipe =
out the 
> iterations themselves.  So it's a radical contrast.  In effect, =
this 
> radical shift away from iteration and local interaction is possible=
 
> because CPPNs are cheating: They can know the coordinate frame 
> withi=
n which they operate a priori- something that is not available 
> in biolog=
y.  So it is not a surprise that when we cheat we can do 
> better.  
> 
> =
Thus, I am arguing an admittedly radical position that classic 
> iterated =
devbelopment is best abandoned as a form of indirect 
> encoding for evolut=
ionary algorithms.
> 
> Please note however, having said that, that iterati=
on IS necessary 
> for developmental systems that interact with the environ=
ment over 
> their lifetime (such as brains).  However, CPPNs can iterate i=
n such 
> a way just as any other system.  It only means re-querying the CP=
PN 
> at each iteration.  Thus, CPPNs do not miss this capability even 
> w=
hen it is necessary (and it will be in the long run).
> 
> Therefore, my hu=
nch is that CPPNs (or something quite similar) are 
> the best type of abst=
raction we will get.  The enchantment with a 
> process of unfolding over t=
ime and local interaction may turn out to 
> be an intuitive mistake.
> 
> =
ken
>
